bring the session to a close.

Having completed his list of suggested changes in Student council
organization, J Murray Kemptom,
senior representative in the body,
yesterday announced that he would
submit his work for approval next
Wednesday.
At the last meeting of the council
a plan for open council meetings was
sanctioned, thus eliminating the necessity of including it in the proposed
reforms.
According to Kempton the report
was completed only after receiving
suggestions the various members of
the thirty-man committee formed
after the recent Cotillion board
purge. The committee was organized
to secure student self-government,
and sponsored a petition and mass
meeting in attempting to reach this
end.
If all four of Kempton's suggestions are sanctioned by the Council, it
is expected that the entire constitution will be rewritten. If only one or
two are passed, however, they will be
inserted in the present document.
Two of the proposals would give
student body rational power in the
control of council action. Kempton
advocates first to broaden the system
of representation by electing members
in proportion to the size of the student body. The second point giving
more power to the students is a system of recall and referendum. Under
this plan the student body would be
able to remove from the council any
representative whom they felt incapable and by the same token would have
the power to vote on all legislation
before it was effected.
Kempton also plans to vest more
power in the council body itself. According to his proposals, the group
would legally be able to control all
undergraduate non-athletic activities and would have the authority to
present advice to the faculty on matters of curricula, etc.
"Our hopes of securing the passage
of these regulations," declared Kemp-ton, "rest largely on reasonable discussion between members of the administration and student body. It is
our wish that in deciding this matter
neither of these groups will be carried
away by predjudice.

general, not confined by race, color, or religion.

Negroes from the University."

staff of the Baltimore City Department of Public

enroll, and the rich will not give.)
